data.title: MAN ALIVE! New chief Milan sees Owls soar.

APA style: MAN ALIVE! New chief Milan sees Owls soar.. (n.d.) >The Free Library. (2014). Retrieved Aug 28 2024 from https://www.thefreelibrary.com/MAN+ALIVE!+New+chief+Milan+sees+Owls+soar.-a0244060558

Byline: DAVE BODMAN

SHEFFIELD WEDNESDAY 6

BRISTOL ROVERS 2

Sedgwick 10, Miller 23, Teale 26, Johnson 32 O'Connor 71, Heffernan 81 Hoskins 7, 66

MILAN MANDARIC watched his first game at the helm of Sheffield Wednesday as they roared into the top two by hitting Bristol Rovers for six.

Mandaric agreed a deal to take over as chairman a fortnight ago and took his seat in the directors box at Hillsborough to find Alan Irvine's team purring.

The win underlined the Owls' promotion credentials as a first-half blitz piled the misery on Rovers boss Paul Trollope.

Wednesday had lost their last two outings but hit back after Will Hoskins had put the visitors ahead.

Rovers felt the full force of the backlash as three goals in nine first-half minutes helped secure victory.

And their miserable afternoon was rounded off by former loanee Paul Heffernan adding the sixth, his first for Wednesday.

The Owls made one change as Daniel Jones replaced the injured Jon Otsemobor, who continues to struggle with an ongoing calf problem.

Rovers also fielded an altered back four, with Byron Anthony coming in to the side.

He returned to the fold after undertaking an extra week's training to help shake off an ankle problem and Trollope's patience was immediately vindicated. The 24-year-old showed no signs of cobwebs on his return and was sharp enough to hand his team a seventhminute lead.

Wayne Brown swung over a cross-cum-shot that had Nicky Weaver in no-man's land, leaving Hoskins the simple task of heading in at the far post.

But that was the best Rovers offered and the visitors could only keep Wednesday at bay for three minutes.

Clinton Morrison worked himself room to shoot at Mikkel Andersen, who was only able to parry the forward's effort.

Chris Sedgwick had the presence of mind to follow up the chance and was perfectly placed to slot in the rebound.

Wednesday - backed on by an ever-vociferous crowd - sensed they could capitalise on Rovers' shakiness and poured forward in search of another.

Tommy Spurr brought the best out of Andersen with a strike from 25 yards before the stopper kept the Owls at bay with another fine save as he turned behind a strike from Jones.

The respite was only temporary as Wednesday's rampant play rewarded them with a goal in the 23rd minute - albeit with the help of referee Colin Webster.

The official appeared to have killed a move with Tommy Miller in possession on the edge of the box, but he eventually evaded the man in the middle to fire past the hapless Andersen.

Any optimism soon evaporated out of the away ranks as they found themselves further behind three minutes later.

The lively Gary Teale was left unmarked in the area and he applied a neat finish for his third goal of the campaign.

Andersen was picking the ball out of his net again after 32 minutes as Jermaine Johnson ghosted into the danger zone to stroke past the Dane. Teale and his midfield colleagues were given too much freedom, and Anthony resorted to a strong-arm approach.

The defender hacked down the winger, causing a melee, but it at least helped the visitors get into the break without further damage.

They rallied and pulled one back when Weaver was caught out by Hoskins' lob, but worries over a fightback never materialised as substitute James O'Connor curled in the fifth.

Teale and Morrison rattled the woodwork before Heffernan came off the bench to polish off a stellar showing that leaves Trollope glancing nervously over his shoulder.

CAPTION(S):

HANDS-ON: Milan Mandaric applauds as Sedgwick equalises in the Owls' 6-2 goalfest
